Boreskov Institute of Catalysis SB RAS Prospekt Akad Lavrentieva 5 Novosibirsk 630090 Russian Federation In this study, the one-pot synthesis of glycidol from glycerol (Gly) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) was demonstrated in the presence of novel composite materials based on the microporous layered titanosilicate AM-4 (Aveiro-Manchester material number 4) and a zeolitic imidazolate framework ZIF-8. It was found that the reaction rate and selectivity towards glycidol depended on the ZIF-8 content in composite. Maximum 74.4% yield of glycidol with 92.5% conversion of glycerol was observed in the presence of 0.5%ZIF-8/AM-4 at DMC/Gly-molar ratio of 2, catalyst/glycerol weight ratio of 7.9 wt.% and temperature of 100°C for 8 h. The catalytic properties of developed ZIF-8/AM-4 composite correlated with (1) ZIF-8 particle size, (2) the decreasing basic sites strength, and (3) the increasing microporosity of materials. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords ZIF-8/AM-4 composite Glycidol Glycerol Dimethyl carbonate One-pot synthesis Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In the last years, the main attention is focused on the developing ways to synthesize chemicals with high added value from renewable raw materials. Glycerol, which is a key by-product of biodiesel synthesis, has significant potential as a building block for the synthesis of organic compounds via the glycerol carboxylation, hydrogenolysis, oxidation, acetylation, reforming etc. [1]. According to literature [2–7], glycerol carbonate (GC) and glycidol (GD) are one of the chemicals which can be synthesized from glycerol (Gly) (Scheme 1 ). Thus, GC is used as (i) a solvent in food, cosmetics, textiles, and pharmaceuticals; (ii) a versatile building block for organic chemistry, for example, for the synthesis of polymers, such as polyethers, polycarbonates, polyurethanes, etc.; and (iii) an electrolyte for lithium-ion batteries. According to Transparency Market Research [8], the global market for glycerol carbonate will grow at a rate of around 7% per year, reaching USD $2.4 billion by 2030. At the same time, GD is used both for stabilization of natural oils and vinyl polymers and as a chemical intermediate in the synthesis of glycidyl ethers, esters and amines. According to Growth Market Reports [9], The global glycidol market was valued at USD 8190.2 million in 2019 and is projected to reach USD 13205.5 million by 2027, expanding at a CAGR of 7.8% during the forecast period. Nowadays, various approaches have been developed for the synthesis of GC and GD (Scheme 1) [10–13]. The synthesis routes of GC include direct carbonylation of Gly-with CO2, oxidative carbonylation of Gly with gas mixture of CO. Other routes based on phosgenation, glycerolisis of urea and transesterification of allyl (cyclic) carbonates and diethyl/dimethyl carbonates. Several methods also have been described for the synthesis of GD (Scheme 1), such as epoxidation of allyl alcohol using tungsten based catalyst TS-1, reaction of 3‑chloro-1,2-propanediol with bases, decarboxylation of GC and transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) [2–6]. Advantages and disadvantages of developed routes for the synthesis of GC and GD are shown in Tables S1-S2 (Supporting Information, SI). Note that rout via transesterification of Gly with DMC (Scheme 2 ) can be considered as a promising method for the production of GC and GD because of the cost-effective reaction and good eco-efficiency. Noteworthy, this route allows to obtain GD by one-pot process [2,3,5,7] and two steps process with production of GC and then its decarboxylation to GD [6,14,15] (Table 1 ). Undoubtedly, one-pot process is a cost-efficient method and more promising in comparison with two step process. Kondawar et al. [2] reported about one-pot synthesis of GD from Gly-and DMC in the presence of mixed metal oxides Ba-M (1:1) (M – Ce, La, Nd) as catalysts. The highest conversion of Gly (98%) and selectivity towards GD (80%) has been achieved using Ba-Ce (1:1) at 120 °C for 90 min. This result was explained by the presence of a CeO2 lattice with defects, which is known to be the best for CO2 adsorption (Table 1). Devi et al. [7] demonstrated that potassium incorporated rice husk (K-RHA) could be used as catalysts for glycidol production with 60.8% glycerol conversion and 62.9% selectivity within one hour of reaction time (Table 1). The one-pot synthesis of GD from Gly -and DMC over NaAlO2 was developed by Bai et al. [5]. This catalyst was demonstrated to be easily recovered and reused. Noteworthy, application of NaAlO2 as catalyst allows to obtain both GC and GD (Table 1). Thus, GC with 98.7% selectivity at 89% conversion of Gly was formed at low temperature like 60 °C. At the same time, the 94.7% conversion of Gly and the 80.7% selectivity to GD were reached under the reaction conditions of DMC/Gly-molar ratio of 2, NaAlO2/Gly weight ratio of 3% at high temperature (80–92°C) for 90 min. In the present study, we investigated the one-pot process between Gly and DMC (Scheme 2) in the presence of composites based on zeolitic imidazolate framework ZIF-8 and layered titanosilicate AM-4 (Aveiro-Manchester material number 4, Na3(Na,H)Ti2O2[Si 2O6]2·2H2O) as catalysts (ZIF-8/AM-4). The choice of ZIF-8/AM-4 composites as catalysts is based on several reasons. First of all, Xiang and Wu recently used a mesoporous titanosilicate molecular sieve ETS-10 with a 3D 12-ring structure and strong basic sites as catalyst for the synthesis of GC at DMC/Gly molar ratio of 2 and 90 °C for 4 h [18]. The modification of ETS-10 with transition metals Ni, Co, Zn, Cu, Fe and Mn by wet-impregnated was found to allow improving its activity. According to experimental data, the yield of GC decreased in the following order: Ni/METS-10 (91.6%) > Zn/METS-10 (89.4%) > Mn/METS-10 (75.5%) > Fe/METS-10 (61.8%) > Co/MET S-10 (53.9%) > Cu/METS-10 (45.3%) > ETS-10 (39.2%). The highest yield of GC (203.7 mmol/g) in the presence of Ni/ETS-10 was explained by the increasing basicity that speeds the interaction of Lewis basic sites (TiO6 2−) with the primary hydroxyl group of glycerol to form the glyceroxide anion. Second reason is investigation of Chang et al. [19]. They used composites based on ZIF-8 and MgO as catalysts for the synthesis of GC from Gly and DMC (Scheme 2). The microporous MgO/ZIF-8 composites with different MgO content were prepared by a two-step procedure, i.e. a wet-impregnation of ZIF-8 by Mg(NO3)2 and then calcinated at 370 °C for 3 h under Ar. GC was the major product. The yield of GC was found to rise from 12.5 mmol/g to 21.2 mmol/g with the increasing MgO content in composite from 10 to 50 wt.%. The 50%Mg/ZIF-8 composite produced more GC (21.2 mmol/g) than MgO (18.5 mmol/g), ZIF-8 (8.3 mmol/g), and physically mixed MgO and ZIF-8 (13.5 mmol/g) after 2 h at a DMC/Gly-molar ratio of 4 and 75 °C. This was explained by a synergistic effect between MgO and ZIF-8. Thirdly, ZIF-8 and AM-4 possess unique structural and physicochemical properties that can affect the catalytic properties of ZIF-8/AM-4 composite. Thus, ZIF-8 combines the outstanding properties of both metal-organic frameworks and zeolites, such as a high specific surface area, uniform cavities, and apertures, homogeneous distribution of active sites, the existence of both acidic and basic sites [20,21]. ZIF-8 is one of the most studied ZIFs based on Zn2+ and 2-methylimidazole (2-MIM). ZIF-8 with SOD networks has large pores of 11.6 Å which are accessible through small apertures of 3.4 Å. In spite of the high efficiency in catalysis and adsorption processes, ZIF-8 possesses some short comings. There is an aggregation of ZIF-8 nanoparticles in polar media that can lead to an increasing particle size and, therefore, lead to a reducing catalytic and adsorption efficiency. Moreover, ZIF-8 nanoparticles are difficult to be separated from reaction mixture which restricts their regeneration and reuse. To solve this problem, scientists switched their focus to the design of composites based on ZIF-8, because such types materials exhibit superior properties than individual components due to the synergetic effect, i.e. the collective behavior of each functional unit [22]. Nowadays, ZIF-8 composites have been successfully prepared with different inorganic and organic materials, such as silica oxides and mixed oxides (MxOy-Al2O3 Si, Zn, Co), Fe3O4 and CoFe2O4 magnetic particles, cellulose etc. (Table S3-S4, SI). The integrating of ZIF-8 into different solids can be realized through different synthesis strategies, such as: in situ [23], secondary growth [24], ex situ [25], the counter-diffusion approach [26], and the LPE approach (also called layer-by-layer or sequential growth) [27–29] (Table S3-S4, SI). A two-step in situ procedure is a versatile synthetic strategy for the fabrication of ZIF-8/composite. According to this strategy, ZIF-8 nanocrystals forms on the surface of solid pre-modified with Zn2+. Such an approach allows controlling the location and number of Zn2+ ions on the surface of a solid. Herein, we synthesized ZIF-8/AM-4 by a two-step in situ procedure. Such approach was possible due to the unique layered structures of AM-4 which consist of interconnecting brookite-type TiO6 octahedra and SiO4 tetrahedra, forming layers perpendicular to the c axis (Scheme 3 ). In general, the structure of AM-4 is like a five-tier sandwich of SiO4:TiO6:SiO4:TiO6:SiO4. The charge on the Ti-Si layers is balanced by sodium cations located in the interlamellar space (exchangeable) and in the space within the layer (structural cations). The investigation of cation-exchange properties of AM-4 pointed that it can be used as an adsorbent for Ag+, Zn2+, Cu2+ [30,31], Cs+ and Sr+ [32,33] and radionuclides 241Am and 236Pu [32,34]. Note that AM-4 also can be used as the catalyst. Thus, AM-4 was used as a solid base catalyst for the synthesis of propylene glycol methyl ether from propylene oxide and methanol [35], the condensation of benzaldehyde with ethyl acetoacetate (the Knoevenagel reaction), cyclocondansation between 1,2-phenylenediamine and acetone to 1,5-benzodiazepine [36], and isomerization of aldo-saccharides (D-glucose, cellobiose and d-xylose) [37,38]. According to Antunes et al. [38], in the aqueous phase isomerization of aldo-saccharides the as-synthesized (sodium form) AM-4 possessed high activity and limited stability towards leaching of Na+ ions. However, the stability of AM-4 can be improved by the substitution of Na+ by K +, Mg2+ or Ca2+. Mg-AM-4 and Ca-AM-4 were more stable than Na-AM-4 and K-AM-4. Note that the amount and density of base sites determined by TPD-CO2 decreased in the order: N a − A M − 4 > M g − A M − 4 > > K − A M − 4 > C a − A M − 4 . According to DRIFT spectroscopy using CDCl3 as a CH acid probe [35] the strength of the basic sites (proton affinity) of Na-AM-4 is 1019 kJ/mol). According to recent advances, chemical composition, structural and textural properties of catalysts can directly affect the reaction selectivity. We can assume that design of ZIF-8/AM-4 composite via modification (chemically and morphologically) of AM-4 allows us to fine tune selectivity reaction towards GC and GD. Moreover, we would like to draw your attention in our investigation to the evaluation of the main factors that affected the textural, physicochemical, and catalytic properties of ZIF-8/AM-4 composites in the reaction between Gly and DMC. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Dimethylcarbonate, glycerol, 2-methylimidazole and Zn(NO3)2 .6H2O were purchased from Acros Organic. Commercial methanol was used without any further purification. Powder of ammonium sulfate oxytitanium (NH4)2TiO(SO4)2∙H2O was the pre-product of sphene concentrate reprocessing (PJSC PhosAgro, Russia). Na2SiO3·5H2O and NaOH were purchased from Neva Reactive and Merck, respectively. All chemicals were used as received without any further purification. The layer titanosilicate AM-4 was synthesized via hydrothermal synthesis in a Teflon-lined autoclave with an inner volume of 450 cm3. Synthesis consists of 3 stages that are explained in (section S3, SI). ZIF-8/AM-4 composites were prepared by two-step in situ approach (Scheme 3 ). Stage 1: Interlayer sodium cations were partially replaced by zinc cations via keeping 0.5 g of AM-4 in 8 ml of an aqueous solution of zinc nitrate for 7 days. The obtained solid was separated by filtration, followed by repeated washing with distilled water and subsequent dryness at room temperature for 24 h. Stage 2. ZIF-8/AM-4 composites were prepared via Zn/AM-4 treatment with 2-methylimidazole in methanol solution at 60 °C for 1 h. Then solid was separated, washed with MeOH, and dried at room temperature for 24 h. 2.2 Instrumental measurements The chemical analyses of the solids were carried out by means of inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES). The diffraction images were obtained with the use of a Thermo ARL X'tra device, with a non-monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å), focusing geometry θ-θ in the scanning mode within the range of angles from 3 to 75°, with a step of 0.05° The porous structures of samples were determined from the adsorption of N2 at 77 K using an ASAP 2020 Plus the Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ instrument from Micromeritics. The specific surface area (SBET) was calculated from the adsorption data using maxima arrangement modification of the BET method [39] over the relative pressure range between 0.05 and 0.20. The total pore volume (VΣ) was evaluated at a p/p0 of 0.99. HRTEM images were obtained on a JEM-2010 electron microscope (JEOL, Japan) with a lattice-fringe resolution of 0.14 nm and points 0.194 nm at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The high-resolution images of the periodic structures were analysed by the Fourier method. Samples for HRTEM examination were prepared on a perforated carbon film mounted on a copper grid. IR spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu FTIR-8300S spectrometer with a DRS-8000 diffusion reflectance cell in the range between 400 and 6000 cm–1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. All spectra are presented in the F(R) Kubelka-Munk scale: F ( R ) = ( 1 − R ) 2 2 R , where R is the reflection coefficient. The point of zero charge of AM-4 samples (pHPZC) was determined by mass titration described in the literature [40]. A pH meter was calibrated using pH 1.68 and 6.86 buffers. All measurements were carried out using distilled-deionized water. 2.3 Catalytic test The reaction was carried out in the glass pressure reactors (a tinyclave pressure reactor Buchi AG) with an inner volume of 25 cm3. Before the reaction, all catalysts were activated at 150 °C for 1 h in air. The standard procedure was as follows: 13.7 mmol (1.26 g) of glycerol, 17.4 mmol (2.14 g) of dimethyl carbonate, and 0.1 g of catalyst were introduced into the autoclave. After 5 h of reaction, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. The products were analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7820) equipped with a flame ionization detector and using an HP-5 capillary column, after separation by centrifugation of the catalysts. Analysis of products were carried out by a mass spectrometer (Shimadzu GCMS QP-2010 Ultra with a GsBP1-MS column, 30 m × 0.32 mm, thickness 0.25 µm) was used to identify the reaction products. Temperature program was the following: 50 °C (3 min) – 20 °C/min – 300 °C (10 min). For all analysis helium was used as carrier gas. The error of experimental measurements was always less than 10% (section S4, SI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and investigation of ZIF-8/AM-4 composites 3.1.1 Modification of AM-4 with Zn(NO3)2 (Step 1) The substitution of interlayer sodium cations by zinc cations into the framework of AM-4 was monitored by FTIR spectroscopy. The IR spectra of AM-4 before and after ion exchange are shown in Fig. 1 and Figs. S1-S3 (SI). In the IR spectrum of the AM-4 sample, broad bands are observed in the range of 400–700 cm−1 and 700–1200 cm−1, which characterize vibrations of the M-O bond and asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the TOx (where T is the central Si4+ or Ti4+ ion) [41–43]. The main types of characteristic bands are described in Table 2 . The FTIR spectrum of AM-4 includes bands at 425, 559, and 690 cm−1 corresponding to vibrations of the Ti-O, Ti-O-Ti, and O-Ti-O bonds of the TiO6 octahedron, respectively [43–45]. The bands at 479, 537, and 997 cm−1 are assigned to O-Si-O (siloxy) bonding vibrations [46] and the stretching of the Si-O-Si bond [43]. The band at 1129 cm−1 is related to Si-O vibrations [47,48]. Remarkably, after the substitution of Na+ ions by Zn2+ all these bands shifted (Table 2). The shift of bands rose with an increasing number of Zn2+ in the framework of AM-4. Moreover, there are the bands at 919 and 939 cm−1correspond to the stretching vibrations of the Ti-O-Si bonds in large and small cavities, respectively, in the spectrum of AM-4 [49]. This suggestion is confirmed by the decreasing intensity of the band at 919 cm−1 with an increasing number of Na+ ions substituted by Zn2+ ions. In addition, the spectrum of AM-4 also shows the band at 1656 cm−1 corresponding to the OH bending of Si-OH and Ti-OH groups located on the surface of the solid. Remarkable, this band shifts after the substitution of Na+ by Zn2+. The shift increases with increasing Zn2+ content into the framework of AM-4. Such behavior can point to the interaction between -OH groups and Zn2+ ions. The ν(HOH) vibrations of chemisorbed water at the active centers of Ti and Si cause a band at 1717 cm−1 in the AM-4 spectrum [50]. XRD study of Zn/AM-4 composites. The XRD patterns of AM-4 before and after modification with Zn(NO3)2 are shown in Fig. 1B. Table 3 demonstrates the unit cell parameters, which were estimated by the method of full-profile analysis (R = 11% in all cases) using X'Pert High Score Plus Program (Version 2.1). According to XRD data, the substitution of Na+ with Zn2+ leads to an increasing a parameter and reducing b and c parameters, as evidenced by the appearance of maxima, the position of which is shifted towards larger angles (Table 3). This is a natural change because the radius of the hydrated Zn2+ ion (Zn(H2O)6 2+) is smaller (0.74 Å [51]) than the radius of the Na(H2O)6+ ion (1.09 Å [51]). Basic properties of Zn/AM-4 composites. The change in the chemical composition also affects the acid-base properties. The change of basicity in the course of the Na+ substitution with Zn2+ was estimated by two approaches. The first approach was based on the method of mass titration [52]. This method is based on the addition of small portions of solid to the aqueous solution and measuring the change in the pH of the system up to the constant value, which is the point of zero charge (pHPZC). Fig. S4A (SI) depicts mass titration curves of AM-4 before and after modification with Zn(NO3)2. These results were used to construct a correlation between the pHZPC and Zn2+ content in AM-4 (Fig. S4, SI). The results of this relationship point out that the increase in the degree of substitution of sodium cations with zinc cations leads to the rising surface acidity (pHPZC) of the Zn/AM-4. The pHPZC changes from 11.2 to 7.7 after the substitution of 10% sodium cations (Fig. S4B, SI). The change in pHPZC agrees with the change in basicity of samples estimated as the optical basicity based on the concept suggested by Duffy [53]. According to this concept, optical basicity (Λ) is concerned with the electron-donor power of lattice oxygen atoms and depends on the oxidation number and coordination of the cations. The values of the optical basicity of samples were calculated using Eq. (1) (1) L = X N a L N a + X Z n L Z n + X S i L S i + X T i L T i where XNa, XSi, and XTiare the equivalent fractions of metals; and ΛNa (1.15), ΛSi (0.48) and ΛTi (0.75) are the optical basicities of Na, Si and Ti, respectively [53]. One can be seen from Fig. S4B, the optical basicity decreases with an increase in the degree of substitution of sodium cations with zinc cations. This is consistent with the difference in electronegativity of sodium (1.036) and zinc (1.336) [54]. 3.1.2 Synthesis of ZIF-8/AM-4 (Step 2) Zn/AM-4 samples were modified with 2-methylimidazole in a methanol solution for the formation of ZIF-8 into the framework of AM-4. ZIF-8/AM-4 samples were characterized by different physicochemical methods. FTIR spectroscopic study of ZIF-8/AM-4 composites. FTIR spectra of Zn/AM-4 before and after modification with 2-methylimidazle are shown in Fig. 2 and Figs. S2-S3 (SI). All FTIR spectra of ZIF-8/AM-4 point to the presence of the characteristic bands of ZIF-8. First of all, the band at 425 cm−1 corresponding to vibrations of the Ti-O into the framework of Zn/AM-4 changes its shape. The band broadening can be explained by its overlapping with the band at 428 cm−1 assigned to the Zn-N stretching mode in the framework of ZIF-8. In addition, bands at 696 and 758 cm−1 (the symmetric out-of-plane bending of the 2-MIM ring and associated motions of the HC = CH bond (ωC–H) present in the framework structure), 1146 and 1180 cm−1 (the symmetrical methyl deformation mode CH3) are observed [55,56]. Note that a shift of the bands at 758 and 1146 cm−1 in the spectrum of the ZIF-8/AM-4 sample in comparison with the position of bands in the spectrum of ZIF-8 (762 and 1152 cm−1) points to the interaction of functional groups of ZIF-8 with functional groups of AM-4. TEM study of ZIF-8/AM-4 composites. The formation of ZIF-8 nanoparticles into the framework of AM-4 was investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The TEM image clearly shows the well-ordered layered structure of AM-4 (Fig. 3 A). The interplanar distances are 0.41–0.42 nm. The 5%ZIF-8/AM-4 sample also has a layered structure. However, the interplanar distances are twice as large (0.81–0.83 nm) in comparison with AM-4 due to the formation of nanoparticles of ZIF-8 into the large cavities of AM-4 (Fig. 3B). Moreover, ZIF-8 nanoparticles of 2–4 nm in size were also formed on the outer surface of AM-4. This follows from the ZnO monitoring after exposure to a light beam on the sample (Fig. 3C). This process is possible because the interaction between Zn2+ ions and -OH groups, and Si-OH and Ti-OH groups should promote the ZIF-8 nucleation on the surface of AM-4 XRD study of ZIF-8/AM-4 composites. XRD patterns of ZIF-8/AM-4 materials with different ZIF-8 content are shown in Fig. 4 . The unit cell parameters were estimated by the method of full-profile analysis (R = 11% in all cases) using the X'Pert High Score Plus Program (Version 2.1). As can be seen from Table 3, the reflection angle (200) shifts from 6.04 to 6.34° (2θ) with increasing ZIF-8 content from 0.5 to 10 wt.%. This shift can point out the transformation of the structure. Thus, after modification of 0.5% Zn/AM-4 and 5% Zn/AM-4 with 2-MIM the unit cell parameter c decreases from 29.26 to 29.18 Å and from 29.32 to 29.16 Å, respectively (Table 3). At the same time, the angle β also changes. However, these changes are in different directions. After modification of 0.5% Zn/AM-4 with 2-MIM the angle β decreases from 90.90 to 90.81°, while in 5% Zn/AM-4 the angle β increases from 90.68 to 90.95° (Table 3). The increasing β angle can be caused by the formation of nanoparticles in the surface defect sites of AM-4 (Fig. 3C). It can be seen from Fig. 4, diffraction peaks of ZIF-8 are not observed in the XRD pattern of 0.5%ZIF-8/AM-4 practically. This phenomenon is likely to be explained by the formation of small or defect particles in the interlayer of AM-4 (Fig. 3B). At the same time, peaks of ZIF-8 are observed in XRD patterns of 5%ZIF-8/AM-4 and 10%ZIF-8/AM-4 samples, and their intensity rises with increasing ZIF-8 content. The indirect method, i.e. the determination of the average size of the coherent scattering regions, was used for the estimation of the crystal size of ZIF-8 in the composite. The coherent scattering region, DXRD values were calculated using the Debye-Scherrer's formula (Eq. (2)) [57,58]: (2) D XRD = 0 . 9 · λ β · cos θ where DXRD is the coherent scattering region (nm), β is the full-width at half maximum of the peak (radian), Θ is the Bragg angle of the diffraction peak (grad), and λ is X-ray wavelength of CuKα (0.1542 nm). According to the results shown in Table S5 (SI), the increasing ZIF-8 content in AM-4 from 5 to 10 wt.% leads to the rising DXRD from 25.8 to 30.7 Å. We can assume that this phenomenon can affect the catalytic properties of ZIF-8/AM-4 materials. Textural properties of ZIF-8/AM-4 composites. Fig. 5 shows N2 adsorption isotherms (77.4 K) in semi-logarithmic and normal coordinates (insert) after normalization to αS values [59], which was performed for scaling purposes. The range of capillary condensation reveals the practical absence of the hysteresis loop for the pure ZIF-8. The noticeable increase in the adsorption amount aspiring p/p° = 1.0 corresponds to adsorption in macropores, most probably between microcrystals. The decrease of the ZIF-8 content in composites results in appearance of the Type H3 hysteresis loop typical for pure AM-4. Unfortunately, Type H3 loops are not appropriate for the reasonable calculation of mesopore volume-size distributions yet [60]. The lower pressure range in normal coordinates allows attribution of the isotherms to Type I, relating the studied samples to microporous materials. Starting from the minimum pressure, the adsorption and desorption branches coincide and reveal two substeps until p/p° ca. 0.006 for pure ZIF-8. There is a hysteresis loop above this pressure, ending with the closure above p/p° ca. 0.03. Such behavior is typical to ZIF-8 and accounts for structural deformation of the framework [61,62]. The distinctive feature of ZIF-8/AM-4 composites is the shift of the hysteresis loops to higher pressure, while primarily filling is identical to pure ZIF-8. In order to explore this interesting observation, we recalculated the adsorption isotherms to the form of d a s d Δ μ vs Δμ, where Δ μ = R T ln ( p p o ) is the adsorption potential (Fig. 6 ). There are three peaks (regions I, II, and IIIa) on the adsorption branch and two peaks (regions I and II) on the desorption branch for pure ZIF-8. The probable explanation for this is the sequence of “primarily filling”-“structural deformation”-“N2 additional loading”. N2 additional loading in to the adsorption-induced expanded structure of ZIF-8 (Region IIIa) is moderately delayed compared to N2 evacuation from it (region IIId), forming the observed hysteresis loop of ca 700 J/mol width. The introduction of ZIF-8 into AM-4 results in the right-shifting of the peak in the region IIIa by approximately 300 J/mol, while the peak in the range II seems keeping its position unchanged. Simultaneously, the peak on the desorption branch splits into two peaks: the peak on the desorption branch has the same position as the peak on the adsorption branch in the region II, while the peak in the region IIId shifts to the right by a similar 300 J/mol. The width of the hysteresis loop does not change. The observed shift of the hysteresis loop is related to the decrease in the average size of ZIF-8 microcrystals [63]. Unfortunately, there is no direct reliable correlation between the microcrystalline size and the hysteresis loop shift. Zang et al. did not observe the adsorption induced structure deformation transition above p/p° ca. 0.035 for self-standing ZIF-8 microcrystals [63]. However, there is evidence of ZIF-8 retaining the transition above this pressure in mixtures with nonporous oxides [64]. Probably, the contact with admixtures can enhance the stability of ZIF-8. Since routine application of the BET method is ambiguous due to uncertainty of pressure range choice even when Rouquerol's consistency criteria [60,65] are applied, we used the MA-BET technique with k = 2 (the direct evaluation) to evaluate the BET parameters. In this form the MA-BET gives the univocal values regardless to additional assumptions. These values are brought to Table 4 . Point B positions (where adsorption uptake equals to the BET monolayer capacity) against the p/p° axis for all samples correspond to the right closure of the hysteresis loops (Fig. 6). The obtained specific surface area of pure ZIF-8, ABET, is very close to the value of the geometric surface area accessible to nitrogen molecules, as it is calculated by means of iRASPA software [66]. The micropore volume estimated by means of the t-method is identical to the apparent volume, calculated by the same ratio n m , B E T ρ L N 2 , but exceeds the geometrically accessible volume of 0.536 cm3/g according to iRASPA. There are two possible reasons: i) possibly higher N2 density in ZIF-8 micropores due to enhanced adsorption potential compared to the bulk, or ii) influence of the structural deformation. We are prone to the former option, although we have no good evidence to prove it. Anyway, particularly to ZIF-8 BET and t-method point to similar content of N2 for the complete micropore filling. One can estimate the average size of ZIF-8 microcrystalls, assuming their apparent density δ = 0.92 g/cm3 as it is calculated by means of iRASPA software [66]. For a regular polyhedron d ( n m ) = 6000 A t ( m 2 / g ) · δ ( g / c m 3 ) , thus the average size of pure ZIF-8 microcrystals is ∼170 nm according to the obtained textural data. This is in good correlation with TEM data (Fig. 3D) but exceeds the size (coherent scattering region) derived from XRD. The latter indicates presence of defects in ZIF-8 structure. 3.2 Catalytic properties of ZIF-8/AM-4 The catalytic properties of ZIF-8/AM-4 composites were studied in the reaction of Gly with DMC (Scheme 2). The reaction was carried out in a glass autoclave at a DMC/Gly molar ratio of 2:1 mol/mol, 7.9 wt.% of a catalyst based on Gly, and 90 °C. The major products were GC and GD due to the two consecutive steps. The conversion of Gly and the distribution of products were found to strongly depend on the ZIF-8 content in AM-4. As one can be seen from Table 5 , in the presence of AM-4 the conversion of Gly was 93.2% for 24 h. This value slightly increased after the insertion of ZIF-8 into the framework of AM-4 up to 5 wt.%. The further increase in ZIF-8 content results in a sharp fall in the reaction rate. The selectivity of reaction towards GC and GD also depends on the ZIF-8 content in composite (Table 5). In the presence of ZIF-8 the major product is GC with 99.6% selectivity. At the same time, both GC and GD are formed in the presence of AM-4 (Table 5). Correlation between ZIF-8 content in composite and selectivity towards GD has a dome-shaped relationship. The maximum selectivity towards GC (78.4%) is observed in the presence of 0.5%ZIF-8/AM-4. This correlation can be explained by several reasons: 1) It is well-known [11–13] that the reaction rate depends on the strength of basic sites. The high basicity provokes the high reaction rate. According to IR spectroscopy using CDCl3 as a probe molecule, the strength of the strongest basic sites (proton affinity, PA) of AM-4 and ZIF-8 are 1019 kJ/mol [35] and 858 kJ/mol [67] respectively. The increasing ZIF-8 content in AM-4 should lead to the decreasing strength of basic sites and, therefore, decreasing reaction rate. 2) Other reason may be the decreasing number of Ti-OH groups due to their blocking of ZIF-8. According to the investigation of one-pot synthesis of glycidol from glycerol and dimethyl carbonate in the presence of KNO3/Al2O3 [16] and tetraethylammonium amino acid ionic liquids [17], the formed GC interacts with Lewis acid site by oxygen atom of carbonyl group. Intermolecular electron transfer gives a ring-opened intermediate, which undergoes decarboxylation through an intramolecular nucleophilic substitution to form GD and CO2. We can suggest that -OH group of GC can interact with Ti-OH group via hydrogen bonding (Scheme 4). Such interaction should favor and thus accelerate intramolecular electron transfer and decarboxylation. The number of Ti-OH groups depends on the ZIF-8 content in composite. An increase in the amount of ZIF-8 in the composite is accompanied by a decrease in the number of Ti-OH groups and, as a result, a decrease in the reaction rate and yield of GD. 1) Early [68], we demonstrated that the activity of ZIFs can be tuned by the variation of particle size. Therefore, we can suggest that the change in particle size of ZIF-8 in framework of AM-4 is also the other factor that affected the activity and selectivity towards GD. The highest selectivity towards GD (78.4%) was observed in the presence of a 0.5%ZIF-8/AM-4 sample with a particle size less than 1 nm (Table 5). At the same time, the increasing particle size from 25.8 nm to 45.0 nm leads to a decreasing selectivity towards GD from 62.9 to 0.4%. 2) Textural properties also can be one of the reasons affect the catalytic behavior of ZIF-8/AM-4 composite. As one can be seen from Table 4, AM-4 is a macroporous (pore width > 50 nm) material with a specific surface area (SBET) about 20 m2/g and a total pore volume of about (Vmicro) 0.07 cm3/g. The formation of 5 wt.% of ZIF-8 in the framework of AM-4 gives rise to the Vmicro (0.017 cm3/g) and a significant growing SBET of 57 m2/g. An increase in ZIF-8 content in ZIF-8/AM-4 composite causes further increasing SBET and Vmicro. The specific surface area and micropore volume of ZIF-8 are 1801 m2/g and 0.640 cm3/g, respectively (Table 4). The increase in microporosity of ZIF-8/AM-4 composites with growing ZIF-8 content can lead to the decreasing accessibility of active sites for the reagents and increasing diffusion limitations and, therefore, the decreasing reaction rate and selectivity towards GD. In order to explain the difference between the catalytic properties of AM-4 and 0.5%ZIF-8/AM-4, we studied the kinetics of the reaction in their presence. Kinetic curves of consumption of Gly and accumulation of GC and GD in the presence of AM-4 and 0.5%ZIF-8/AM-4 are shown in Fig. 7 and Fig. S5 (SI). Experimental data point that in the presence of AM-4, a slow decrease in the yield of GC is observed. This behavior can probably be explained by the leaching of Na+ ions from the AM-4 structure. The stability of samples was studied by the “hot filtration” method. The reaction was stopped after 5 or 8 h, the catalyst was quickly separated by filtration through a heated funnel. The filtrate was again loaded into the autoclave and the reaction was continued without a catalyst for 5 or 8 h. According to experimental data, the conversion of Gly increases after the separation of AM-4 (from 58.5 to 62.8% and from 68.5 to 74.6% after 5 and 8 h, respectively), while the Gly conversion changes insignificantly (from 58.5 to 59.2% and from 75.2 to 76.0% after 5 and 8 h, respectively) in the case of 0.5% ZIF-8/AM-4 (Fig. S6, SI). Thus, the introduction of ZIF-8 into the structure of AM-4 makes it possible to increase the stability of the system with respect to the leaching of Na+ ions. Note that investigation of stability in cyclic test also points the decreasing efficiency of AM-4 after first cycle (Fig. S6, SI). After first cycle, AM-4 was separated from the reaction mixture via conventional filtration, washed with methanol (3 × 10 ml), kept in MeOH for 1 days, dried at room temperature, reactivated at 100 °C for 1 h, and then used in the next cycle. Reaction was investigated at molar ratio of DMC/Gly of 2, 7.9 wt.% of catalyst (based on glycerol), 90 °C and 12 h. In second cycle conversion of Gly and selectivity towards GD decreased from 74.8 to 60.6% and from 52.1 to 16.4%, respectively. At the same time, insignificant changes of conversion of Gly (from 80.3 to 78.5%) and selectivity towards GD (from 59.4 to 58.6%) were in the presence of 0.5%ZIF-8/AM-4. 4 Summary Here we demonstrate the synthesis of novel composite materials based on the layered titanosilicate Aveiro-Manchester material number 4 (AM-4) and the Zeolitic Imidazolate Framework ZIF-8. ZIF-8/AM-4 composites with different ZIF-8 content were synthesized according to a two-step in-situ procedure. In the first step, the interlayer sodium cations were substituted by zinc cations in the framework of AM-4. In the second step, ZIF-8 particles were formed in the course of a solvothermal procedure due to the modification of Zn/AM-4 samples with 2-methylimidazole. XRD, TEM and N2 adsorption analysis data revealed that the particle size of ZIF-8 grows with increasing ZIF-8 content in composite. Nitrogen adsorption at 77.4 K shows that increasing ZIF-8 content increases specific surface area and micropore volume. Catalytic properties of ZIF-8/AM-4 materials were investigated in one-pot synthesis of glycidol from glycerol and dimethyl carbonate (DMC/Gly molar ratio of 2, 7.9 wt.% of catalyst based on glycerol, 90 °C, and 24 h). Maximum yield of GD (73.8%) with 78.4% selectivity was observed in the presence of 0.5%ZIF-8/AM-4. A further increase in the number of ZIF-8 in the ZIF-8/AM-4 composite causes a decreasing reaction rate and selectivity towards GD. In the presence of ZIF-8 conversion of Gly-and selectivity towards GD were 71.3% and 0.4%, respectively. According to our observations, this correlates with (i) ZIF-8 microcrystal size, (ii) a decrease in the basic site's strength, and (iii) an increase in the microporosity of materials. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the one-pot synthesis of glycidol from glycerol (Gly) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) was demonstrated in the presence of novel composite materials based on the microporous layered titanosilicate AM-4 (Aveiro-Manchester material number 4) and a zeolitic imidazolate framework ZIF-8. It was found that the reaction rate and selectivity towards glycidol depended on the ZIF-8 content in composite. Maximum 74.4% yield of glycidol with 92.5% conversion of glycerol was observed in the presence of 0.5%ZIF-8/AM-4 at DMC/Gly-molar ratio of 2, catalyst/glycerol weight ratio of 7.9 wt.% and temperature of 100°C for 8 h. The catalytic properties of developed ZIF-8/AM-4 composite correlated with (1) ZIF-8 particle size, (2) the decreasing basic sites strength, and (3) the increasing microporosity of materials.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of glycidol via transesterification glycerol with dimethylcarbonate in the presence of composites based on a layered titanosilicate AM-4 and ZIF-8
